sub_title: Assistant Professor at CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)
summary:
I'm assistant professor of Latin American Studies at the University of Amsterdam - Centre for Latin American Research and Documentation (CEDLA). Trained as an anthropologist, I'm specialized in ethnographic research on violence, (dis)order, (prison) governance and state-(un)making, particularly in Nicaragua. Currently I also work on these topics in the city of Amsterdam, as PI on the research project "Het Ongelijkheidsbeginsel" (the principle of inequality), which takes a holistic approach to understand the ways in which urban inequalities (spatial, socio-economic and racial/ethnic) are mitigated and/or reproduced through criminal justice interventions.

At the same time, I continue to research practices of (para-)policing, imprisonment, state crime and organized crime in Nicaragua. In relation to the 2018 protests and their aftermath, I work with (former) political prisoners and their family members, Nicaraguan exiles and refugees, and human rights activists. I am currently working on two book projects. The first is a volume co-edited with Hanneke Stuit and Jennifer Turner, which is titled "Carceral Worlds" (Bloomsbury). The book critically explores the expansion of carcerality in our globalized present and how this may be unsettled. The second is a manuscript based on my doctoral thesis, which was awarded a cum laude distinction. The thesis, "Performing Prison: Power, Agency and Co-Governance in Nicaraguan Prisons", was based on 31 months of multi-sited ethnographic research conducted between 2009 and 2016 with long and short-sentenced (former) prisoners of three Nicaraguan prison facilities. This book is about the ways in which prisoners negotiate power both inside and outside their cells, documenting and theorizing the emergence of Nicaragua's hybrid carceral state.

In general, I am interested in the day-to-day workings of prison life and the (development) of carceral/penal states, policing and other forms of non-state/extralegal surveillance and governance. In doing so, I focus on questions of (il)legitimacy, violence and the body. I participate actively in a number of interdisciplinary networks on confinement and prisons research, including the Global Prisons Research Network (as a co-organizer), the EASA Anthropology of Confinement Network (co-convener 2018-2022), and the Americas Prisons Research Network/Red Penitenciaria de las Americas (founding member), with whom I organize various events. 

I'm always open to collaborations and exchanging ideas. Feel free to write me at j.h.j.weegels@uva.nl. Take care!

projects:
[{'title': 'Het Ongelijkheidsbeginsel: Tussen Strafrecht en Stadsdeel', 'date': {'start': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'description': 'Het strafrechtsysteem heeft een sterke invloed op de doorontwikkeling van ongelijkheid in verschillende levensdomeinen en levensfasen: zo hebben niet-witte jongeren in bepaalde stadsdelen een grotere kans om in aanraking te komen met justitie, en is een strafblad een van de meest beperkende factoren van volwaardige participatie in de samenleving. In dit project onderzoeken wij de relatie tussen het strafrechtsysteem en de cumulatie van ruimtelijke en sociale ongelijkheden. Het onderzoek heeft als doel om beter inzicht te geven in de manier waarop strafrechtelijk beleid (op stads- en stadsdeelniveau) invloed heeft op de kansen en hulpbronnen van Amsterdamse jongvolwassenen zowel voor als na de periode van de strafrechtelijke sanctie. Op basis van interviews met jongvolwassenen en medewerkers van het Openbaar Ministerie, Reclassering en Rechtbank Amsterdam, beschrijven en begrijpen wij hoe strafrechtelijke procedures vormgeven aan sociale en ruimtelijke scheidslijnen, en dragen wij samen met onze partners bij aan het aanpakken van ongelijkheid binnen het strafrechtsysteem.

Partners in dit project zijn: 

UvA – Centre for Urban Studies 
UvA – Centre for Latin American Research and Documentation (CEDLA)
Universiteit Utrecht – Criminologie
KennisWerkplaats Vrijheidsbeneming en Maatschappij
Restorative Justice Nederland', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Julienne', 'last_name': 'Weegels', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Assistant Professor at CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)'}]}, {'title': 'Theatre in Prison / Teatro en la Cárcel', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2009}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': None, 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Julienne', 'last_name': 'Weegels', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Assistant Professor at CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Mick', 'last_name': 'Sarria', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Sociedad Leon Teatro en Lleca Teatro Independiente  , Nicaragua'}]}, {'title': 'Tracing the Nicaraguan Prisoner: Moving between Marginality, Violence and Change', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': "PhD Research Project, abstract:

Though by definition restricted in their mobility prisoners are in many ways as mobile as any other citizen – perhaps even more so. They move between scripts, from ‘delinquent’ to ‘changed man’ and back, crossing and bending the symbolic and real boundaries of the prison compound. As ‘delinquents’ they are key transgressors of social order. Locating this research in the midst of the prisoner’s processes of participation, adaptation and resistance to the institution’s order and its re-educational programs, is to locate it at the heart of the conflicting ideas that set the ‘delinquent’ aside from ‘society’ and define what he must become in order to return. Nicaragua’s mediated imagery of crime, struggles of power over the state institutions of control and reconfigurations of the pandilla (street gang) delinquent 'style', all directly reflect on the prisoner and his environment. The ability or inability for social actors (such as prisoners) to move between differing ideas and behaviours – those of violence and those of change – becomes a pivotal element of their success, both inside and subsequently outside of prison, be it in either of the worlds. These processes of moving are at the heart of this ethnographic study. It is through the prisoner’s shifting identities, bodily artefacts, narrative expressions, and movement through time that this research attempts to shed a light on what prison means to long-sentenced prisoners and ex-convicts in Nicaragua.

Field research periods: March-November 2013, October 2014-June 2015, September 2015-January 2016.
Supervisors: Prof. Dr. Michiel Baud (CEDLA), Prof. Dr. Dennis Rodgers (University of Amsterdam).
", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Julienne', 'last_name': 'Weegels', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Assistant Professor at CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)'}]}, {'title': 'Beyond Bars / Más Allá de las Rejas', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'Beyond Bars was a prisoner rights project financed by the German Embassy in Nicaragua.

With this project I hosted a former prisoner radio show, co-produced a prison theatre tour, and co-facilitated a prison arts program. Beyond Bars also published a short guide "Un Acercamiento a los Derechos Económicos Sociales y Culturales de la Comunidad (Ex) Privada de Libertad," and a penal policy recommendation to help strengthen prisoner social, cultural and economic rights and their reinsertion. During the project, I taught participatory action research methods at the diplomado 'Prevención Social del Delito' (Social Prevention of Crime) at the UENIC-MLK, Managua. Incarceration is a continuous publication journal.', 'title': 'International Advisory Board member', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 2040736, 'name': 'CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D0BAQHRJgvCbXTmSA/company-logo_400_400/0/1519895814795?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=ncuSE9IB7xwUye03f1jfqehJJZzu134qyzOamyg5QBw', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/cedla-university-of-amsterdam-/', 'employees': {'start': 11, 'end': 50}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2009}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Amsterdam, North Holland, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)', 'description': 'In terms of research, I am the PI for the research project P(R)OTESTAS: The Politics and Aesthetics of Digital Authoritarianism and Protest (GDC Seed Grant 2021). I am also part of the research project ILLICITIES: City-Making and Organized Crime, led by Frank Muller with the Centre for Urban Studies. Aside from this, I am engaged in grant writing for a multi-sited research project on the hybrid enforcement of punitive politics in Central America. For all of the above, I continue to conduct research on the emergence, evolvement and workings of Nicaragua's hybrid carceral state.

In terms of teaching, I currently coordinate the MA courses "Introduction to Latin American Studies" and "Latin American Studies: Deepening the Debates", teach an MA tutorial on Violence, Governance and (In)Security, supervise MA and BA theses, and teach the BA elective "Gender and Social Inequality in Latin America" and qualitative methodology course "Interdisciplinary Methods" at the BA and MA levels. Aside from my course teaching, I provide guest lectures on violence and social exclusion, policing and prisons, the (un)rule of law, extralegal governance and illegal economies, drugs, social policy toward (criminalized) youth, and ethnographic research methods.

I am also coordinator of the Latin American Studies Programme (LASP), an interuniversity graduate programme for PhD students working on/in Latin America, for which I organize a Summer School and a Writing Retreat every other year.', 'title': 'Assistant Professor', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'company': 'CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)', 'description': 'Following the 2018 anti-government protests, I developed a research project on Nicaraguan practices of authority, justice and sovereignty from below. This research project takes the key findings and material from my prisons research as its point of departure, combining it with new research on the changing practices and understandings of policing and confinement in Nicaragua today. In particular, it investigates the government’s strategies of repression and crisis in legitimacy at the hand of its para-state organization, while also seeking to understand the protesters’ divergent claims to the state under the banner of justicia and libertad. In doing so, it focuses on the practices and claims to sovereignty by groups of autoconvocados (self-convened protesters), and the state’s extralegal governance techniques (including torture and political imprisonment).', 'title': 'Postdoctoral Researcher', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'company': 'CEDLA (University of Amsterdam)', 'description': 'At CEDLA I have developed and teach the MA course "Violence, Governance, and (In)Security in Latin America". volunteer_experiences:
[{'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'role': 'Co-Organizer', 'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Global Prisons Research Network', 'logo': None, 'url': None}, 'cause': 'EDUCATION', 'description': 'www.gprnetwork.org 

"Contemporary prisons beyond the West are under-researched and ill-understood, though often subject to critique and condemnation. The Global Prisons Research Network aims to fill the empirical gap created by the hegemony of the Anglo-American axis of comparison in prison studies by promoting and supporting in depth studies of prison practices in Africa, Asia, the Middle East, Latin America and the former Soviet States.

Our aim is to illuminate prison life on the basis of critical, research-based understandings of prison practice and prison actors. The network will encourage ethnographic perspectives on prison practice and challenge the reduction of prisons in the global south and in transitional societies to examples of failure to live up to international best practice, norms and standards."

On 2-3 November 2017 the I organized a roundtable conference at the University of Amsterdam together with the SECURCIT research group's chair prof. Rivke Jaffe and GPRN-founders Andrew Jefferson and Tomas Max Martin. The conference was titled "Connecting Urban and Prison Ethnographies: Security and Confinement beyond the Limitations of Site." It was generously hosted and co-funded by the UvA, DIGNITY (the Danish Institute against Torture) and subsidized by the Netherlands Royal Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW). Following the conference, we edited a special issue bringing together the conference's most thought-provoking papers. This issue is forthcoming with the Cambridge Journal of Anthropology in June 2020.
